newsitem.title: USA: General Mills to fund schools in cereal promotion.
newsitem.headline: General Mills to fund schools in cereal promotion.

text.p: General Mills Inc. , whose stable of cereal brands includes Cheerios and Wheaties, Monday got a hand from Olympic gold medal winner Amy Van Dyken to announce a nationwide program to help elementary schools raise needed cash.
Under the program elementary schools will receive 15 cents for each special box top turned in, up to a $10,000 limit per school.

"We all know that schools all over the country are struggling for funds to bring kids the best possible education," said General Mills spokesman David Dix. "General Mills wants kids to have a good start with a good breakfast and a good education."
Van Dyken, the winner of four gold medals for swimming at this year's Olympics who recently appeared on a Wheaties cereal box, denied that the program brings corporate boosterism to the classroom.
"I don't think it's (about) buying a product. I think that it's more getting a point across - that's it's for education," she said in a brief interview.

The Minneapols-based food giant, which holds a 24 percent share of the cereal market, is offering the program to any of the 85,000 elementary schools in the United States, including parochial and military schools.
The promotion, which will accept boxtops from any of General Mills' 37 cereal brands, is in force until March 31.
